Either way it was interesting and I loved it though without the fat content of an older cow I don't know how to order it.  I went with rare, as usual, but it was a little chewy.  All the other portions at the table were totally unfinishable and we only shared the empanadas (amazing) for apps and the burger topping salads.  My brother got some kind of giant platter with 2 kinds of sausage, short ribs, something else, and sweetbreads (I LOVE SWEETBREADS!) for $18.  The only reason Tango Sur doesn't get the 5th star is for their short ribs which are inexplicably not braised but grilled.  Like braising a tenderloin this just doesn't work.  Among our many doggy bags was a container of short ribs that I braised at home the next day (they were delicious) but that shouldn't really be part of going out to eat.

Reviews.Author: Kara B.
Reviews.Content: Tango Sur is arguably the best BYOB restaurant in the city. The only thing that makes it lose one star is the wait -- no reservations so plan on being their a while. They don't really have the place well set up for the large number of people waiting for a table either. The food, however, is excellent and the portions are large enough to feel a small family. Their empanadas are wonderful, and even those family members suspicious of the mildest forms of ethnic food will be satisfied here. It is essentially a wonderful steakhouse. The prices are very reasonable, so if you want to buy an amazing, somewhat fancy dinner for very little, this is the place to go!

Reviews.Author: Vanessa R.
Reviews.Content: First let me start by saying go to Tango Sur with the mindset that you will be waiting, and that it is not a rushed meal, slow down your speedy Chicago lifestyle and enjoy it. It is so worth it. Tango Sur, is one of the best restaurants on the Northside in my opinion. When we have out of town visitors, or are celebrating something special, we take them to Tango Sur. It is BYOB, there is a CVS that sells alcohol and and a little store next door that does too. It is a long wait on weekends but like another poster said, they will take your cell phone number and you can walk just about anywhere to get a drink on Southport. The steaks not only taste amazing, but they are very inexpensive. I have no idea what kind of seasoning goes into the cooking process but they are so tender, and and have so much flavor that you just want more. I think the portion sizes are larger than most steak restaurants here in the city and their side dishes are also awesome. My favorite are the Vesuvio Potatoes, and be sure to try the Empanada's too! Sometimes it seems like service can be a little slow, it reminds me of when I am on vacation some places and you have to actually ask for the check. The perfect time to go here is on a non--Cubs game night midweek.

Reviews.Author: Henry A.
Reviews.Content: 4.5 stars maybe....There are a lot of great things about Tango Sur:- outside seating- BYOB- very reasonably priced- massive portions (if you can eat that much)If you are a meat lover, you will probably love this place just for the humongous portions of steak you will get served here at damn good prices.  Since it's BYOB too, you really can get a great deal without breaking the bank.  The "El Filet" is only $23 and you get TWO filet mignons - that's right: 2 of them.  I don't think you can beat the value of this anywhere.  It's not the best steak I've ever had, but it's decent.  However, I always get the feeling that they are more about quantity than quality here.  Dont' get me wrong, it's not bad food at all, but I'd rather they give me a little less and make it a little better instead.  I don't need a plate with 2 whole steaks for dinner.  If you're the kind of person that does, though, you will be in heaven here.My recommendation for two "normal" eaters: bring a bottle of wine (or two), get the "El Filet" with the two steaks and an appetizer and share.  You'll have a great evening and walk out with well under $40 total for steak dinner for two.  Be prepared to wait forever to get a seat.  You definitely want to make reservations ahead of time.

Reviews.Author: Tony L.
Reviews.Content: I've been holding off on going to this place for a while, mainly because I don't particularly like the neighborhood it is in and parking there is horrible (yeh yeh, duh CTA but these days I'd rather drive...FU CTA).  As we walked up to this place we could see there was a pretty big line and lots of people around.  We were expecting a pretty big wait for it being labor day weekend and all.  We put our name in and gave them our phone number (pretty cool IMO, they'll call you when your table is ready) and we went down to the local bar and had some drinks.  We waited an hour and half and rarely do I wait this long for food.  We had a party of 5, some had been there before and said the food was worth it, so I obliged.The place was pretty crowded, seating was pretty close together and kind of hard to see with most of the light coming from candles on the tables.  We ordered from the specialties menu and got orders for 2 (the vacio and lomo ren-something, i could barely read the menu because it was so dark).  We also had the grilled provolone type cheese and 5 beef empenadas.  The appetizers were pretty good, the empenadas I've had before and they are awesome.  Then came the main courses that came on these stands.  I could barely see it, but I could totally smell the garlic and mushrooms and the sweet potatoes looked great.  They tasted even better.  I was surprised at how good the food was and I really liked the style they presented the meat.  Steak lovers, you will love this place.  If I had some rice, I would have cleaned the platter the meat came on, the sauce was that good.  The price was very reasonable.  120 for five of us.  Not bad.  I took a star off because I don't like being crowded and I felt like I was being crowded with all of the close seating.  Tango Sur may be my favorite place in Chicago.

Reviews.Author: Tiffany H.
Reviews.Content: Good Vegetarian dish and BYOB!!!!Well, let me start out by saying that this place is ALL ABOUT MEAT. Being a vegetarian (again), I was a little bit weary that there would nothing for me to eat. While there was only one vegetarian dish available, it was all I needed. The Eggplant Parmesan was absolutely fabulous! Not only was I impressed with the how the good the dish looked, but the flavor was amazing. I've tasted many failed attempts at Eggplant Parmesan that are just put on the menu to be vegetarian friendly. Tango Sur really put some thought and flavor into this dish. The creamy tomato sauce was what did it for me. It was rich, but not too rich to where I thought I was going be paying for it later :) Vegetarians- please don't be afraid! Aside from the good Eggplant, the atmosphere was dimly lit by candles and very romantic. I recommend this place a great date spot or a intimate dinner with close friends.

Reviews.Author: i.am.a A.
Reviews.Content: If you ever been to Argentina, or had a real south-american style parrillada, DON'T GO HERE. The only thing this place has going for it is that it's BYOB. You have been warned, so no bitching later...Now, if you are parrillada-curious and want to have a ROUGH idea of what this is about, go and check it out.The servers have a couple of empanadas stuffed up their butts, and it only gets worse if the place gets packed (which doesn't help).

Reviews.Author: Katie G.
Reviews.Content: Oh man, after the appetizers and a few glasses of BYOB wine, I really really really wanted to like this place!Then my meal came.First things first: the appetizers were great.  Melted provolone on a plate?  Yum.  Sopping up the cheese-grease with bread?  Divine!  As per other reviews, the empanadas were awesome: perfectly puffed and filled with deliciousness (I had one meat and one spinach ... my friend got a  ham-and-cheese and loved it, even though it is a little weird sounding).About the dinner.  Dum dum dum ...Maybe I should know better than to order the fish at an Argentine "steak" house??  Blech!  The Tilapia itself would have been okay if it were not smothered in this indescribably awful tangy orange syrup.  I am an adventurous eater and try to eat a few bites of everything to make sure but it was seriously gross and I was gagging by Bite Three.  My friends across the table got this big hunk of meat and mushrooms (recommended "for two"): the thing could have served the entire table of 12.  Except that no one would eat it because the meat was texturally-challenged and completely over-seasoned (read: mushy and saaaaaalty).  Strike 2!Tango Sur never actually struck out.  Again, the appetizers were great and the management/servers allowed us to bring in a cake for the birthday we were celebrating.  Service was attentive and friendly.  Overall the meal was not a complete waste (no Strike 3), but if I go back, I will only eat empanadas.

Reviews.Author: iddells E.
Reviews.Content: So glad we didn't go to Wildfire (my brother's choice for his birthday).  But instead, I suggested that we try out Tango Sur, which I've been wanting to try for the longest time.Bottom line is that you get a lot of delicious meat for you what you pay, but you have to wait a really long time for it.  I ordered the churrasco, which was a 12-ounce juicy steak, my brother got the filet mignon, which he loved, and my mom and aunt shared the para dos sampler, which was interesting and huge!!  I was able to try blood sausage, which was alright.  But I loved the throat sweetbread.....so crunchy and tasty!We came at around noontime....great time to go since it wasn't crowded and we were seated right away!    Service is friendly and attentive.  I'll be returning, probably one evening with my husband.

Reviews.Author: Jennie T.
Reviews.Content: I seriously need a new dining partner here. I've only came here with an ex, and well, ex's are ex's for a reason... I don't like to stay close to them. I like the empanadas here. It's a lot better than other empanadas I've had in the city. We ordered a spinach one and a beef one. I liked them both. The beef one was especially juicy, and I like that a lot. We also ordered the jamon crudo con melon, which is Prociutto served with cantaloupe. It was delicious. I never knew that Prociutto paired so well with cantaloupe before! Salty meets semi-sweet. Perfection.The first time we came here, the ex-girlfriend ordered us a huge 16 or 32 oz. T-bone steak covered in red chimichurri sauce. I'm not a big fan of steaks or of meat in general, so I thought it was way too much meat. I prefer something closer to 8 oz or less. Needless to say, I ended up boxing it up to go. So the second and last time we came here, I specifically asked her if we can split a smaller meal. We ended up ordering el filet, which was topped with a red onion wine sauce and served with spinach mashed potatoes. I loved this selection way more than the first. I also liked that it was not covered in sauce. Don't get me wrong, I like sauce... but not too much. Tango Sur is a BYOB place. It also looks like they've expanded in the two years difference that I've visited it. They now have a waiting room in the back, but it's so dimly lit that it'd make for awkward conversations if you don't like your companion. The restaurant is best for dates... by yourselves or on double dates. I wouldn't come here with a group larger than six. You'd have a hard time hearing one another as it tends to be very loud here. They do take reservations so make yours before you go. The wait can be extremely long.

Reviews.Author: Abs T.
Reviews.Content: The last time we went to Tango Sur, we were made to wait an extra 2 hours past our reservation time.  The front door guy was very rude and lied to us a couple times. The food was just OK.....nothing great.  Also, seating was a bit cramped.  I would rather not have someone be rude to me, sit in tight quarters and eat just OK food after waiting 2+ hours.  Thanks, but no thanks.

Reviews.Author: Kate W.
Reviews.Content: I've been here twice.  I don't remember what I ordered, but I remember thinking "I wish I made more money so I could eat here more often."The portions were huge, but that's not a bad thing.The service was also really good.  Fast, polite and professional.I really can't remember anything about it that I didn't like other than that I couldn't afford to go there more frequently.

Reviews.Author: Christian E.
Reviews.Content: As a fan of South American steakhouses and carnivore enthusiast, I had high hopes and expectations from Tango Sur, based on several friend recommendations.  While imperfect, it certainly is now one of my favorite spots in Chicago.Best cab it there because parking is one of the worst I've seen in Chicago, with permit parking only signs everywhere!  We had to eventually settle on parking on Ashland, and walk about 3-4 blocks.Reservations are recommended especially for bigger parties, asyou may be in for a long wait on busy nights.  We were told there was a 45 minute wait for our two party table, and the host offered to call us on our cellphone when the table was ready.    Also, don't forget, it's BYOB!  My biggest complaint was the ambiance.  It was dark, loud and quite cramped, with candlelit tables.  Me and my date were a bit nauseated from some candles that the busboys snuffed out next to us, but luckily it didn't completely spoil our appetite.  If they expanded the restaurant and brought in better lighting and ventilation, I would easily have given this restaurant 5 stars.  The bread rolls were soft and warm, but I was a bit disappointed, expecting traditional South American type breads (can't have it all I guess).  Before our entrees, were were served a simple yet fresh salad plate.  I ordered "El Filete", which was a ~$20 meal with generous and absolutely delicious medallions of fillet mignon, in a red onion type sauce.  The side was a buttery spinach mashed potatoes.  The  Chilean Carmenere wine we brought along went well with the beef. At one point during dinner I speculated that this was one of the best steak dinners I have had in a long time, outside of the other vastly more expensive steakhouses like Ruth Chris.  Cooked to a perfect medium.  Excellent deal and quality.  To note: the menu claims that the beef they serve is Argentine, but I was skeptical about this claim given the ban on Argentine beef imports to the US.The service I suppose was adequate, given the busy night.  We finished the dinner on a higher note with the Dulce de Leche (aka Manjar) flan, which was a dish that tasted exactly as my Chilean aunt would make it.  Authentic Cono Sur flavor!My next round at this restaurant will include samplings of empanadas and a parrillada.  Buen provecho!

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: How come I didn't review Tango Sur earlier? It is one of my FAVORITE restaurants in the city! I don't usually eat steak, but I make the exception here. Try the El Fillet- it is amazing. Every time I go with someone new I recommend it and when they don't order it and try mine, they always say its the best! It is 2 HUGE tender pieces of fillet mignon and comes with the most delicious spinach mashed potatoes. Also try the cheese appetizer- its also a winner! The atmosphere is adorable... very European and romantic. It is it dark and lit by candlelight. It is BYOB which keeps the bill low ( they don't charge a corkage fee!), and the prices are already reasonable. Not to mention that every meal here is so big you can definitely share. They do not take reservations so there is almost always a wait, but they do take reservations for large parties (over 10 I think).

Reviews.Author: Milo M.
Reviews.Content: BYOB Argentinian Steak house with a youthful, latin-euro-style charm.  Light is dim, tables are close.  There is usaully a wait, bring a bottle of wine for the room in the back or hit a nearby bar.  They serve warm fresh bread soon after seated- off to a good start.  Most of the portions are massive- enough for lunch the next day.  I usually get the Churrasco- (steak frites).  The chimchurri (garlic, parsley, olive oil) sauce is the best version around- a difficult task.  The cuts of meat are not premium filets, but this is not a stately steak house- this is a glimpse into the cuisine of Argentina and we are blessed to have this establishment in Chicago.Carne asada at Nuevo Leon, 24-hr marinated steak at Ja'Grill and and even Uncle Julio's (I know it is a chain out of Texas- don't hold it against them) are also some of the best I've had.

Reviews.Author: Jeffrey P.
Reviews.Content: Love this place!  I remember going here about 4 years ago before they were on Check Please.  Went on a Saturday night, got a table right away, had an incredible meal, the bill was small and I was pretty excited.  Aside from being able to get a table right away, everything else good about this place continues to stand today, despite the incredible popularity.Went on Saturday night with a group of 4.  Put our name on the list at 6:45 and went for some drinks across the street with the hope that we would be seated around 8:15 (after the college bball game was over).  Lo and behold, phone rang at 8:14 that our table was ready and off we went.  We brought 3 bottles for two guys and two girls and were seated after about 20 minutes and one bottle of wine in the back room waiting area.  Given that we all had a long night ahead of us, we decided to go heavy on appetizers and split some entrees.  We started with the antipasta as well as a handful of empanadas.  The empanadas are superb, coming in chicken, beef, ham or spinich flavor with each being better than the last.  This was probably not the time or place for a cold antipasta dish but it was fine regardless.*Important note.  I was outvoted in terms of getting the Provoleta appetizer which is pretty much a plate full of hot melted cheese mixed with olive oil and roasted red peppers.  Somehow, it actually tastes better than it sounds so make sure to get this as putting the cheese on bread, empanadas or steak is just incredible.On to the entrees.  My girl and I split the El Filet while our two friends split the Bife Vesuvio.  I can honestly say I have been to this restaurant 30 times and never strayed from either of those two dishes.  The filet is actually a pair of filets in a red wine sauce over garlic mashed potatos.  It was cooked perfectly and we were both stuffed at the end.  The vesuvio is a thicker cut of meat stuffed with spinich and cheese and needless to say, all plates were fully clean by the time we were done.Atmosphere at this place is great with the dim, candlelit dining and noisy, but not too noisy ambiance that allows the soft latin beats to be heard over the voices in the crowded room.We topped it off with some chocolate cake and espressos and everyone left smiling.Despite the years of popularity, Tango Sur continues to hold up to the high standards placed on them and continues to excel.  Great place for dates, groups, events, or just to go have a great meal at a reasonable cost.Without a doubt, this is a top 3 place in Chicago for me.Only downside was when my two friends across the table started making out in the middle of the meal.  Really?  Was that necessary?

Reviews.Author: Blythe Z.
Reviews.Content: Well my friends are obsessed with this place.For a group of 7 with no reservation on a Friday night we were seated at 11PM (got there before 7).  Yes, Yes, I know we didn't make reservations.... we waited at Hye bar down the street.  Bathrooms.... need work, I mean unless their staff has a private bathroom .... eeek! it was really cruddy and dark.  The place is dark in general - I almost couldn't really see what I was eating.  I'd prefer a bit more light so that I can see more clearly what I am eating and the person sitting across from me. The place is very small to every inch is used.  The food was okay - the service was very fast.  It was a good meal - maybe my expectations were too high from everyone always talking it up.  The food was good  - the price was great - BYOB -  I'd suggest checking it out.

Reviews.Author: John M.
Reviews.Content: I was disappointed with my visit to Tango Sur on Saturday, August 29.My recommendation to the owner;1) Better quality flatware and sharp knives2) Better quality of beef, more inspection of what you are buying3) Serve food hot4) Improve the dining room acoustics A busy evening and with our reservation we were seated immediately, the table was a little tight but at least the seating behind us were not hitting our chairs.  Waiters were prompt, friendly, and knowledgeable.  Ambience was loud and once the dining area filled you could hardly hear the person across from you, you literally had to shout and by evenings end I was horse from shouting.  It seems the louder became the higher they turned up the music volume.  They definitely need acoustics work in the building.The flatware was of the most inexpensive grade and the knives needed sharpening.  The forks were so cheap that the tines were crooked and bent on many of them.  When you serve beef/meat sharp knives are essential.  If the meat isn't tender a sharp knife is always a great cover.Enjoyed the BYOB which encourages spending a leisurely time for dinnerNone of this would matter much if the food had lived up to its reputation.  Our party of eight all ordered a different entrées.  I can only speak for 4 of the items; 1) The eggplant was favorable but came to the table lukewarm, like it had sat too long on the plate.2) The T-bone was so full of fat to be nearly inedible and could not be cut no matter how hard you worked3) The short ribs were not favorable and tough4) The sirloin steak was editable but flavor was totally lacking and also had more fat that you would normally expect.If this is a "meat restaurant" they need to upgrade the quality of the meat they purchase or find a chef that knows high quality beef (the entree cost demands this).  Then they need serve the food HOT, this is beef, and beef should be eaten sizzling coming out of the kitchen and if you can't achieve that you really shouldn't be in this business.

Reviews.Author: Jeremiah Z.
Reviews.Content: I honestly debated here whether to give this place 3 stars or 4 stars as I feel Tango Sur is a mixed bag.  Yes the steak is amazing...particularly for the price.  Yes its a hip restaurant that everyone loves.  But the service is questionable at times.....I've had to send a couple steaks back because I'm the type of person that will never pay for a steak if it isn't cooked the way I like.  And getting into the restaurant is a nightmare as well as we all know and once you're inside, its not spacious at all.  The noise level borders on humerous and its very dark in there which might be an issue for some.  I often wonder if the place would be as popular if they got rid of their BYOB policy, but thankfully that remains intact.  And the food quality is excellent when they get it right....its truly one of those places people crave every few months or so.  Overall, its definitely a place everyone in Chicago should try and I do think you get good value for your money.  You just have to be willing to put up with some possible snags in your evening when it comes to getting in there.

Reviews.Author: Sarah G.
Reviews.Content: I had heard great things about Tango Sur after a friend visited here and raved about it, but I had a truly mediocre, if not terrible experience!While the host who seated us was fine (even noticing that the table we first sat at was a little cramped for my long-legged boyfriend and I and moving us instantly), our server was genuinely terrible.At first I thought he was just a little busy, but by the end of the night it was like he was too busy or annoyed to talk to us! He never explained the menu and when we were choosing between the two "Ideal for two" items on the menu, didn't explain the differences at ALL. All he said was "This one is a filet, the other is a flank" and walked off.We chose the flank and I don't know what we were expecting but this was NOT it. The meat was stringy, fatty, difficult to cut, and even more difficult to chew. It was almost like stew meat, and while the seasonings were excellent, they couldn't save this cut from being just plain disappointing.No one wants to be stuck with a cut of meat that takes 5 minutes to chew every bite. I can't help but think that if only our server had bothered to take the time at all to describe that actual differences between the cut, we would have been a lot happier. So perhaps that's just how that bit of meat is supposed to taste, but it's the server's job to let you know what you're getting into!So disappointing. This place was too expensive and too underwhelming to be worth coming back to.

Reviews.Author: Stacey Z.
Reviews.Content: This place is amazing!  This was my second time to Tango Sur.  My best friend from back in the day was visiting and she said she wanted a steak.  It was a Sunday night and I didn't want to do the whole expensive Morton's or Ruth Chris's etc.  I wanted something quick, affordable, with a good atmosphere.  I knew instantly... Tango Sur on Southport.This place was extremely crowded both times... probably because the food is so damn good!  They give generous portions and the filet, spinach mashed and salad is to die for!  I received two filets... perfect if you like leftovers!  In addition, I like that it is BYOB, which keeps the cost down.  I love this place, as did my friend.  I will definitely be back!!!! =)

Reviews.Author: Jenna S.
Reviews.Content: Definitely one of the best restaurants I have ever been to in the city.  We started out the night outside at a table on the patio and it started pouring!  The wait staff was very helpful in getting us a table inside the restaurant; they quickly accommodated everyone who had been stuck in the rain.Our dinner service was a little slow, but there was some confusion because we had moved to a new table from the patio (we had a new waiter).  The service overall is just right, though, especially for a nice romantic dinner; the waiter isn't hovering but he doesn't disappear.  We ordered and appetizer for both of us and an entree each; I'd defintely recommend either a light appetizer or none at all - there was way too much food!  It was all delicious, but the appetizer was so good that it sort of ruined our entree appetite.  We got the melted queso platter which was amazing... I'd definitely recommend if you have a large party.  I got the blackened steak entree which was - hands down - the best steak I've ever had.  My boyfriend had the breaded veal chop and he really enjoyed it.The BOYB setting makes this place even more amazing.  Definitely recommended to everyone, especially steak lovers.

Reviews.Author: Anne S.
Reviews.Content: Allison E. and I had a lovely time here Sunday night!  I have read so many great reviews about this place, so I wanted to try it.  It was good, but I think it was too pricey for me (I'm cheap, but also extremely picky about steak and like my dad's the best).I can't decide if I liked dining by candle light or not.  In a way it makes the restaurant romantic, however it is also very dark.  I think candles are very romantic when it's just 2 people, however sitting a foot away from strangers in a crowded restaurant takes away some of the romance.The filet Allison had was incredible.  The green mashed potatoes were amazing!  I ordered the churrasco special.  It was tasty, and a lot of meat.  (I ate till I was full Sunday, and then had the leftovers for 2 more meals).  The vesuvio potatoes were nothing special, if you could substitute the spinach mashed potatoes for them you should!I think this would make for an excellent ladies night out.  Everyone would appreciate the romantic atmosphere.  It's byob.  And there is plenty of tasty food!

Reviews.Author: Samuel M.
Reviews.Content: Lots of meat for not a lot of money. Provoleta (bubbly bowl of broiled Argentinian provolone) is a must-order appetizer. I've had most of the beef options on the menu and all are excellent; the parillada (a massive grill overflowing with cross-cut short ribs, blood sausage, and other delectable cuts) stands out for its size and variety. The chimichurri sauce that comes with everything is a perfect complement. Also, it's BYOB, which is always an amazing perk. Service is not the fastest, but the place is small and constantly swamped. Still, Tango Sur doesn't handle the throng as efficiently as possible; we came here once with a massive party and they lost the reservation. Were it not for my extremely affable and convincing friend, we likely wouldn't have eaten here that night. Nevertheless, I had to search the recesses of my memory for this element of the experience; I hardly remembered it because the food was so good. In short: when you're craving a lot of meat served in South American fashion, the Brazilian steakhouses aren't your best option. Tango Sur is way more authentic, and gives you 2-3 times as much bang for your buck.

Reviews.Author: Will V.
Reviews.Content: I have been wanting to go to Tango Sur for a long time, so I finally got Mike and Scott to agree to go there last night. The atmosphere is cozy and earthy, and totally unpretentious. We were greeted immediately at the door, and seated right away even though Mike and I were still waiting for Scott, at about 6:15 PM. The restaurant was not too busy, but by the time we left about 90 minutes later, it was packed.We started off with several appetizers... cold veal with olives and vegetables, empanadas of different varieties, and jamon with melon. All three were very tasty. I think I liked the empanadas the best. At $2 each they are not huge, but nicely sized for appetizers.We were served small salads with greens, tomatoes, and onions, with vinegar and oil dressing. There was nothing terribly fancy about the salads, but that did not bother me a bit, I was trying to save room for the steak. We all ordered the same dinner, El Filet. Our dinner plates arrived and looked so amazing. They came with two rather large filets, at least ten ounces each, by my estimate, and some green (very green!) mashed potatoes. The potatoes were so good, whipped with spinach (hence the green), garlic and Parmesan cheese. The filets were tender, juicy and full of flavor. Au jus covered the plate, and added a little extra zing to the steaks. I loved it.Tango Sur is everything David Burke's Primehouse is not. I'm big on price/performance when it comes to restaurants, and Tango Sur scores big by this metric. It is unpretentious, and the food is so tasty. Did I mention it is BYOB with no corkage fee? How perfect can you get?

Reviews.Author: Katie H.
Reviews.Content: I'm  not sure why I'm even writing a review for Tango Sur, given the atrocious wait, it's clear all of Chicago already knows how great it is! The empanadas are fantastic and at $2 each I wish I had ordered more. The filet was humungous - and juicy, tender, and perfectly cooked medium rare. We shared it and between the two of us, we only finished one of the two medallions (they were great for dinner the next night too!) For dessert we shared a caramel cake topped with a glob of sugary sweet fresh caramel. It was actually on the small size, thank god, and we were able to share it without me feeling like I had blown my diet for the week.  We also started with the provoleta which was pretty much just a bowl of melted cheese. It was good, but it dind't blow me away enough to justify the calories. Service was great , the food was awesome and it's BYO which makes it even better. We ended up with a quality, filling, and amazingly delicious meal for $45 for two. The wait was pretty long, but you can go to Take Five and have some mediocre drinks there while you wait, or if you bring some extra wine, you can grab a wine glass from the table and sit in Tango Sur's wating room (in the back by the bathrooms) and enjoy a drink there while you wait.

Reviews.Author: Taryn T.
Reviews.Content: This is a great date place in the sense that it's dark, candle-lit and cozy, but I definitely wouldn't call it "romantic" - that is, unless you're turned on by the thought of shouting "So how was your day?" over all the noise in this very crowded, popular Lakeview steakhouse.That said.. I still give it the thumbs-up as a date spot for sure. The food is great regardless of what you order - I honestly don't even remember which steak dish I got, but it was large and delicious like every other item on the menu. This place is a carnivore's all-around safe bet. (And actually, even my vegan roommate finds things she likes here.)Like the zillons of other reviewers have already noted, it is BYOB, and they don't take reservations unless you're in a larger group. There were still a few tables for two open when my date and I got here at 7 p.m. on a weekday, though I'd definitely expect a wait on the weekend.

Reviews.Author: Lucy G.
Reviews.Content: GREAT PLACE. I heard that this was not a place for non-meat enthusiasts so I stayed far away until one amazing night. NOT TRUE!I had a great time. We had a late dinner outside and brought two bottles of wine with us (that may have something to do with my love of the place) . You can't beat the outside seating, people watching, BYOB with no corking fee, and a great inexpensive dinner. The food was fantastic, we had empanadas to start, salad and split two entrees, waaay to much food. It was wonderful my favorite part being the spinach and cheese empanadas. Our entire bill came to $23.00 TOTAL. Unreal. They also called my cell phone when our table was ready. If I could give Tango Sur  10 stars, I would.Going back next week, and that's how I feel about that.Went again last night with my restaurant club. LOVE IT STILL!!! Out of 11 people every single one loved it.

Reviews.Author: Tom R.
Reviews.Content: As we walked down the street towards Tango Sur for our Saturday Night, 7:45PM reservation for 7, we walked through a group standing in front of The Music Box at which point my pants instantly became tighter... no, not from the excitement and anticipation of eating at Tango Sur, but from the ambiance of hipsters in the area. Yes, you can get a "contact hipster" just by walking through a group of them. Thankfully we survived, but we should have noted the omen as we got to the restaurant. Tango Sur only takes "reservations" for groups of 6 or more, we had 7, perfect. We had called almost a week prior to dining and expected to wait no more than 15-20 minutes. I'm not unrealistic, I know that even with a larger group and a reservation, you're not going to get seated right on time. However, what I was not expecting was to be told it would be 45 minutes.... which then turned into 90 minutes. But don't worry, at about the hour mark we were lead into a back "waiting room" which felt like an old Chinese opium den, but instead of opium it was wine and instead of toothless, chinese tweakers, it was disgruntled people waiting for tables at a mediocre restaurant. Definitely not a place a woman would want to be alone...2 bottles of wine and 30 minutes later our shackles were finally broken and we were liberated to our table. We started by cracking 2 more bottles of wine to try and wash the opium flavor out of our mouths and then ordered chicken and beef empanadas as well as some sort of cheese plate. The beef empanadas were actually really good and brought me back into the spirit of the food. I almost just ordered 2 more plates of those for my entre, but sadly I did not and regretted it later. The waiter eventually made his way back to us and took our orders... everyone ordered El Filet. I was actually going to order something else, but the waiter successfully up-sold me to the filet-medium. The salads came out and I was a little disappointed. As my fiance pointed out, the lettuce and tomato looked like what you would get on the side when you order a cheeseburger. Literally 3-5 pieces of lettuce flat on a plate with 2 slices of tomato on top of it; oil and vinegar are your only dressing options. Not too long after the salads our filets came out. If I had known that each filet order was 2, 8-10 oz filets more of us would have shared, especially since mine was definitely medium rare and not medium. The medium rare steaks at the table were still breathing. The filet sat in a pool of sauce, which to me usually means they are trying to mask the flavor. The steak wasn't bad, the sauce was good and the spinach mashed potatoes were ok... needless to say I wasn't impressed with the food we waited almost 2 hours for (with a reservation). As you can tell I was quite disappointed with Tango Sur in almost every aspect. Sure it had a nice intimate, candle-lit feel to it, but when the restaurant is louder than the bar watching the Blackhawks game that night, you lose all that intimate appeal. Mediocre food and a 90 minute wait, 30 of which was spent fearing for my life, is not the way to get me to come back. Sorry guys, unless you're really dying to try this, I would pass.

Reviews.Author: otilia p.
Reviews.Content: Don't let my 2 stars mislead you.  This place truly does have excellent food.  However, my 2 stars are for the HORRIBLE service they give to their potentional customers.  My party of 13 arrived around 7:45pm and we were made to wait over and 1hr and 1/2!!!  Typically I don't mind the wait, but the host at this place was a total douche.  He might as well have said, "Um...go somewhere else because there's no chance we'll seat you", but instead gave us the most sarcastic and indifferent attitude. I have no patience to wait for food...no matter how good the food is when they treat people like crap.It's a shame because they do have awesome food, but I can't stand the pretentious attitude.  My only guess is that our group didn't fit in with the "wrigleyville" type.  I used to go here when noooooooo one knew of this place...before the days of "Check Please"....I just hate to see how arrogant they've become.Instead, we left and went to an awesome Italian restaurant on Wilson Ave.....Cara Mio.  At 9:30pm they were quick to take our reservation and had us seated by 9:45.  Accomodated us in nice private room and gave us excellent service.Tango sur...can suck it.    They need to learn better customer service...

Reviews.Author: Chris D.
Reviews.Content: Tango Sur, oh my BYOB friend. You are truly topnotch joint. I always eagerly enjoy accepting offers to eat there.Ah yes, the wonderful Steaks... Hmmmm.. Bone in Ribeye, Medium cooked with Spinach and Potatoes. How can there possibly be Vegetarians in this world?? Well Run by the management staff there. The service has always been professional and attentive every time I have gone.Check em out if you have not already. Invite me please!!! :)

Reviews.Author: Kimberly N.
Reviews.Content: It was my first time--and I will likely return. My boyfriend and I went on a Tuesday, and had no wait at 8pm. The service was fast and attentive. We dressed up a bit for our anniversary, though the table next to us was a group of guys in jeans drinking Corona--either approach seemed appropriate. We had a cheese appetizer (literally: it was melted cheese) that was very good, followed by El Filet (we split it--seriously... split this thing).  The filets were underdone for medium, but pretty good , and certainly worth the price.  I think I'll try something else next time.the flan was heaven. Split that one too.In short: go on the week, bring wine, split it (for $5), have a fancy romantic dinner on the cheap.

Reviews.Author: William W.
Reviews.Content: In the land of great steaks in Chitown, Tango Sur is by far the best steakhouse in my humble opinion if you consider all the key factors in a restaurant: ambiance, $, level of service, and most importantly, quality of food. I definitely agree with the general consensus that this is the #1 date spot with it being BYOB. I've come here with my family, group of friends and dates before; and the steaks here have impressed everyone equally. My usual dish here is the El Fillet with spinach mash potatoes. What's great about the service is if you tell the waiters that you are planning to share the dish, they would actually cut the steak into two pieces for you. And believe me, the portion is enough for two people if you are sharing appetizers and desert. In my latest visit, my date and I decided shared this chef's special appetizer, Berenjena. I've never been a fan of eggplant but somehow I enjoyed this one quite a bit. At the end of the day, my date was happy and my wallet was happy. So win win. I also want to point out that little backroom that Tango Sur has, which essentially serves as the bar/waiting area. There are trays of glasses ready to go so people can just sit there and enjoy the wine that they brought. Very thoughtful on their behalf indeed.

Reviews.Author: Feng Q.
Reviews.Content: To avoid the 2 hours wait as everyone says, we came here at 5:30 on the Sunday night. Brought 2 bottle of wines with us as well. One last table left, surprise surprise! Listen to the recommendations from waiters, people! They know what is good. We ordered 4 different steaks for each of us, and tasted around others... YUMMY! I'm not a meat person, so I even couldn't finish the half of the steak, which the size is about as big as my head. But everything tasted perfect! And the simple old fashioned candle make the whole experience even better. Anyway, a hint for everyone wants to try here:Only on Sunday they take RSVP for 4! If you don't want to wait.

Reviews.Author: A. Claire C.
Reviews.Content: Be warned this place takes forever to get seated. No "reservations" are accepted. There's a guy with a list and a pen at the front with whom you check in with, and check n with, and check in with and then after  about 3 hours you might get a table. Luckily, my group of 5 actually did (after 3 hours). To be honest, I was not very impressed. Not worth the wait. Granted the night before, my group went to Ruxbin's and had a glorious experience. So I had extremely high expectations. I really tried not to, but after that long of a wait, you expect something amazing.I suppose if you were a steak lover, then you might find this place appealing, but I guess I'm not that much of a carnivore or I have really high standards for meat. This place is for the steak purist. This is a no fuss, BYOB, potato tortilla ( hint this is not a traditional tortilla), BYOB, wait for 3 hours for a hunk-a-chunka piece of red meat kind of place.I shared a rib eye with a friend along with the potato tortilla, and some empanadas and I was stuffed beyond stuffed. I definitely didn't finish my food, partly because I was full but partly because I didn't find my food very appealing. The meat was way too fatty. The potato tortilla was not what I expected. It was more like a frittata and not so much a tortilla the way I know of tortillas. The salad was very atypical of what you would expect for a salad - it was 2 large lettuce leaves, a slice of tomato and a slice of red onion with a DIY dressing of oil and red wine vinegar.I think the true test of a restaurant comes to this, would you come to this place again? To that I would answer, no. Maybe if I lived in the Chicago area, but since I don't, I'm more inclined to try other restaurants, vs. coming to this establishment again. So, my advice, go here once, if you are in the area and try it for yourself. But, come here knowing that you might have to wait an hour or more for a table, and that you shouldn't expect a fancy 5 star steakhouse.

Reviews.Author: K. N.
Reviews.Content: Well, The service was perfectly fine and i got there around 5:40 on a Sat and was seated immediately.  The food was very good, but my partner who had the El Filet (and ATE THE WHOLE THING) said his two filets were both cooked differently.  I had the beef vesuvio and it was tasty and humongous.  Unfortunately I forgot the leftovers at the table.  I didn't find it all that cheap, I guess.  The appetizer (baked cheese) and dessert were just OK.  the dinners were very good.  I will go back.  I just wish my partner wasn't such a big eater that we can't share and save money!

Reviews.Author: Victoria L.
Reviews.Content: I remember before I even went to this restaurant while I was walking by with my friends, we were so amazed by it.  It was in the summer and they have outside seating, so people were having their meals and they looked AWESOME, all that meat! When I finally wen to give it a try, it didn't disappoint me.  It was a very nice and intimate restaurant.  Indeed, I had my birthday party there and we all had a great time.One thing to remember is that the steak is a little mixed, by that I meant, it's usually nice and juicy, but last time we went there, it was a little dry.  And also, if you want to medium, you probably have to order it medium well, otherwise you would get a steak dripping with blood.Another thing is that if you ever plan going there during weekends, be prepared to wait for a long time.  Luckily, there's a restaurant/bar right next to it, so you can go there and grab a drink while waiting for your turn to be seated.

Reviews.Author: Suzanne M.
Reviews.Content: Great prices.  BYOB.  Romantic.  Empanadas are delicious.  Vesuvio steak is delicious.  Parrallada (sp?) is basically an entire cow.  The cow is delicious.A little loud...a little cramped...and the wait was 45 minutes...but you know what, if that's the only thing I can say bad about it, then that's a pretty great review, especially for having eaten there only once.Advice for anyone going there for the first time, based on my mistakes:  Remember to eat bread.  If you are drinking your BYOBooze, all that meat will be delicious, but it won't help absorb the alcohol.  Balance it out with some bread.  You can always take home the rest of the cow later.  I walked out of there feeling much "happier" than I had expected to feel, but I basically ate nothing but beef all night long.Viva la sweetbreads - those things were the best.

Reviews.Author: Scott B.
Reviews.Content: It's my birthday week, so I had the urge to go celebrate with a LOT of wine, and had hopes of consuming some good prime steak. Kind of like ex-Bull Dennis Rodman, I celebrate my birthday week not just the day itself. We started by walking up to the much hyped Tango Sur at 9:45 on a Saturday night. The pompous host-not a maître d', took our name, cell # and promised to call within the hour. While patiently waiting down the street at Cullens, for well over an hour, we walked back to Tango Sur. When we walked up to the host stand, pompous host himself looks at us, asks what we need. Wife: {scowl on face} Me: Welllll, I'm " Scott B." and you said that you'd call "within the hour?" Pompous Host: Oh, Scott, I tried calling you. Me: I pulled my phone out of pocket, and showed him that there were no missed calls. Pompous Host: Uhhhh, oh, maybe I called someone else. Me: Uhhh, yeah, maybe that's the case. The pompous prick of a host, walked in "to check" if a table was available. About five minutes later, he, from a distance, waives us inside. I guess he skipped the manners class as a child? With so much hype and extreme demand for a table, I was expecting to see Hugo Chavez and Sean Penn sharing a bottle of wine. Fortunately, this was not the case, but the place was buzzing. After finally being seated, I opened my mind, and was looking forward to Tango Sur living up to their Yelp-a-tation. About 10 minutes later a server came by with some wine glasses, and opened our bottle of wine. (No corkage fee) Both wifey & I did notice that the prices seemed quite low for the entrees. The server took our order, and both of us opted for the "El Filet" at a very reasonable price of $24. As discussed, the server took our order, but not without asking on 3 separate occasions if we wanted an appetizer. I wasn't aware that after 38 years, I just picked up a speech impediment? About 30 minutes later (getting hungry), the "El Filets" were delivered to our table. Jesus! What a lot of meat! The "El Filet" is actually 2 filets, that are probably at least 10 ounces each. Of course I was thinking, how the hell could they sell "prime" beef at these prices. The "El Filets" were accompanied with spinach mashed potatoes. Now, these were some damn good mashed potatoes. The filets though were average, at best. Granted, they were prepared at a perfect medium rare, but this "grass fed" crap was hardly prime beef, in my opinion. What I do credit Tango Sur on is the brilliant marketing team that successfully presents this sham as a first class place for steaks. Brilliant, absolutely brilliant! Just place a trendy restaurant in the affluent Southport corridor, and they'll come! Won't return. I'll gladly pay $42 for a true prime steak at Kinzie, Keefers, or Ruth's, where I'm treated like a majority shareholder, and the quality of the steaks are second to none.

Reviews.Author: Penny P.
Reviews.Content: What's not to love?BYOB, great salads and warm bread, empanadas with garlic sauce, and sharing a big plate of meat and sweet potatoes over a grill.I've probably been to this restaurant more times than any other in the city, and it's because it's always consistently fantastic.   We love to take two bottles of red wine ('cause we inevitably end up drinking one while waiting for a table!) and order the Vacio to share.   In fact, when we were in Napa we actually bought a few bottles specifically for our next trip to Tango Sur.  Oh, and it's Southport, so you also get in some good people-watching, which is always a plus for nosy gals like me.

Reviews.Author: Alli L.
Reviews.Content: Oh Tango, how I love thee. 1. Cheap, good steak - if you've been to Argentina, you know that this restaurant does it up authentic. Their meat is very tender, and they have great chimichurri sauce. Their eggplant appetizer is sooo good. The portions are big.2. It's BYOB - c'mon, that's major points right there! (Except when the over-eager waiters and busboys cleared away my very-sentimental bottle... I suggest you be careful if you bring a bottle that you want to keep)3. It's dark and lit by candles. Cute in a dim, noir, semi-seedy way. Good for groups; they have a back room for private parties.Only con? The wait. Ohhhh the agony. Call in advance for reservations (they take it for small groups, not for huge groups). It helps if you show up 2 hours before you want to eat, deliver your name, and then go off somewhere to stave off your gnawing hunger. But at least they will call you when they've got your spot.

Reviews.Author: Nikki C.
Reviews.Content: Bring the wine.Bring the empty belly.Bring the friends to drink the wine and to enjoy the time as you fill the belly.Bring much patience, a cell phone and a plan b as the time to get to sit at your table will be long(especially during popular dining times).(they will phone you when table is ready so hope for good weathers to stroll the street of Southport)...or go up the block to the DQ and start with your dessert of the frozen creamy things.Bring the people who likes the flesh of the moooooo mooos.Moooooooo Cow;-)Bring the expectation of sitting in a crowded space surrounded by many others waiting to feed their hunger for tearing flesh apart with their incisors.yum yum big meat.empanadas, bread...all foreplay to diminish your meat consumption.f8ck that ish and just order 2 steaks...one for an app and the other as a main course....hell order another steak for dessert.yay mooooooo!

Reviews.Author: Steve M.
Reviews.Content: Tango Sur.  A great place for your inner carnivore!  We showed up on a Sunday night around 8:45, and were able to get an outside table almost right away.  (A huge suprise considering everything folks say about long waits.)It's got the ambiance thing down.. inside: dim lights, dark wood, chill music and candles make for a romantic, intimate dining experience.  Great date spot.  Outside (on a warm night): you get less of the dimness and a little more of the breeze out there.  The service is friendly and attentive.  One server even saw that we were looking at their shirts (which at first seemed to feature a guy's head w/ a funny hat and a crazy moustache, wearing a red bowtie, amongst the words "Tango Sur").  He came right up and got us all learned on how the owner of the place is Argentinian, the guy on the shirt is the most famous singer of tango music in Argentina, and that the restaurant literally means "Tango from the South."On to the food.  We ordered some empanadas to start.  This was definitely the right call.  My favorite was the ham and cheese!  Other notables were ground beef (with some potato bits in there) and the spinach one.  We also got a chicken one, but if I had to choose, my favorite empanadas would be in the order just mentioned.  After that, we popped for the Paradilla para dos.  The sampler for two.  The biggest fr()*#)$@(* portion of meats I've ever had plopped down on a table in front of me!  There were short breads (glands).  There was blood sausage (kind of weird).  There were skirt steaks (yummmmm).  There were short ribs (droooolllll).  There were other pork sausages!  All served up with some lemon wedges for the squeezing and some chimmichurri for the dipping.  A brief word on Tango Sur's chimmichurri sauce.  It is DELICIOUS!  It enhances and compliments the flavor of everything we put it on.  However, prepare to taste the garlic well into the following day.  It's worth it, just make sure you bring mouthwash with you!  Ha!  Finally, the booze.  BYOB!  Our total tab was something like $40.  It got reverse sticker shock.  I mean, for a dinner like this, I'm accustomed to paying at least $80!  Just goes to show how much booze really adds to your bill at regular (NBYOB) restaurants.  I'll DEFINITELY go again.  Tango Sur, you tangoed your way straight into my stomach and heart.

Reviews.Author: Julia J.
Reviews.Content: I feel like such a Debbie downer writing this, but honestly, I just don't get the hype about this place, except to say this: Have you seen the movie "Alive"? (umm, spoiler alert, I guess) You know the part where they find the other half of the plane with the suitcases and one of the dudes opens it and finds toothpaste? He squeezes the toothpaste into his mouth like it's the best thing he's ever eaten because the only thing he's had to eat in a really long time is his teammates? Well, I think the hype about this food just comes from waiting too long. By the time some of these other reviewers sat down, they'd eat toothpaste and call it the best meal ever. I'm not buying it. This is one of those places we've been wanting to try forever since it always gets good reviews, but anytime we think of it, the wait is too long. So, my birthday rolled around on a Tuesday night and we figured that it would be a good night to go to try this place. We made a reservation. When we got there, there was only one other table, so we had our pick of tables and had no wait. To start, we picked the wrong table. We sat outside at a two-top close to the window so we'd be out of the sun. Unfortunately, a leaky air conditioner from a window above had completely saturated the awning, so we were dripped on throughout the entire meal. The place was packed by the time it wasn't really funny anymore, so there was no where for us to go. I know this wasn't necessarily the restaurant's fault, but maybe they should not put a table there? Just a thought. Our waiter came over to the table, opened our bottle of wine (leaving the foil torn and jagged. Such a small detail, but it was noticed) and left us with empty water glasses for about 10 minutes. Finally, someone came by and gave us some water. They dumped some bad bread rolls on our table and away they went. A few minutes later, the waiter returns and says "are you ready to order?" Now, call me picky, but good service usually includes the waiter introducing himself and asking if we'd ever been there before. The menu was not really self explanatory, but the waiter seemed in too much of a hurry to ask. We took a stab and ordered what looked good.  We ordered 2 empanadas- one con carne and one with spinach and cheese. Both were good. However, the busboy came and swept away our plates before we were finished. Just because I put my fork down does not mean you can take my plate. I hate that! Next were the salads. I understand this is a steak house, but the salad was pretty disappointing. The lettuce was not fresh at all, and that's pretty much all the salad is: lots of wilted lettuce, 2 slices of tomato, 3 slices of onion, oil and vinegar. It was bad. Next came our steaks. I had the boneless strip steak. My husband had the short rib. The steaks were good. I ordered mine medium rare, and it came out medium rare. It had a good flavor to it. However, it was really fatty (is that normal for a strip steak? I don't even know), and the knives were really dull so it was difficult to cut. My husband ordered his medium and it came out medium well but he enjoyed it. Then our bill came, and it was less than we spent at a local pub a week ago, so they have that going for them. I'd go between 2 and 3 stars for this place, so count this as a 2.5 stars. Decent steaks and good prices, but no frills. I don't understand the wait for this place. I wouldn't wait more than 10 minutes for this meal, and that's just because I know I'd be getting a deal on a steak, which is never really my first choice when eating out anyway.

Reviews.Author: Mike P.
Reviews.Content: I think I've just about played out my string at Tango Sur.  I was there for a dinner party last night and one of my fellow dinners was treated "less than excellent" by our server.  She just wanted to be sure that she received the correct entree, and as a result was subject to a 5 minute interrogation by our server and the manager.  Not as bad as I'm making it sound, but not OK for one of the best steakhouses on the north side.  Also, while I'm sure there was no malice intended and it might be partly due to a language barrier, when serving a female customer her food, saying "Here's your steak, lady"  sounds pretty derogatory.  Again, my perception of the event probably exaggerates the situation and otherwise service is good and the food is great.  And good for them that they fill the house every night.  I just think I'm ready to move on to other places.  Maybe I'm just getting old.

Reviews.Author: Christy L.
Reviews.Content: Tango Sur is one of the best values in Chicago!  A BYOB Argentine steakhouse, you can get in and out for less than $50 a couple.  In fact, if you're not a huge eater, I recommend splitting an appetizer and entree between two people, and you could probably eat dinner (with wine) for less than $30!  The fillet dinner is actually two 8-9 ounces tenderloins, which are easily shareable.  Other cuts of meat are also large though not necessarily already split in two.Be prepared to wait if you arrive after 6pm on weekend night!  It's no secret that Tango Sur is such a great value.  There is a small room in the back where you can start imbibing while waiting to be seated.  Also, the restaurant is loud, which makes it challenging with a large group and/or older dining companions.

Reviews.Author: Christmas D.
Reviews.Content: I would go 3 1/2 stars if I could...I really like this restaurant so I was surprised by the very mixed reviews.  Perhaps consistency isn't their strong point.   Anyway...I've been here a few times but I will review my most recent visit.Five of us walked in early Sunday evening and were seated right away.  I was concerned that they wouldn't have seating for little people but it turns out they are a very family-friendly place.  I found the staff to be very attentive.  Our waiter explained the difference between the beef offered on the menu (from Canada) and that offered on the specials menu (South American).  He was very helpful in recommending dishes.We skipped the apps. and just ordered entrees.  I was pleased to discover that entrees came with a salad but it did leave a bit to be desired.  It was iceburg lettuce with onion slivers, tomato, served with oil and vinegar.  If they had just chosen a better lettuce I probably wouldn't diss it at all.  But a salad is such a simple thing to improve upon seems an easy way to up their ratings.I ordered the Bif Vesuvio, medium rare.  This is, hands down, one of the tastiest steak dished I have ever had.  However, despite my temperature request, the meat was WAY too rare.  Actually, all of our steaks were significantly more rare than we'd ordered them.  I suppose it's better to undercook than overcook.  Had my son not been with us I would've sent it back for them to cook more.  Instead, I ate the ends (which was actually plenty) and took the rest home.  by the time I reheated the leftovers, it was cooked perfectly!The sauce they serve the steak with is super-garlic-heavenly (they gave me extra to take home with my left-overs), the potatoes were AMAZING.  Other than the undercooked meat, the rest of my family was also quite pleased with the place and have said they will definitely go back.

Reviews.Author: Brad B.
Reviews.Content: Tango Sur has been reviewed to death already So, I'm just going to keep this brief.Great food. Good value for money. BYOB. Sorta random but, really gracious service. Gets quite busy because of all these things. Plan accordingly. Bring your patient hat. Leave your damn pram at home.Totally enjoyable. Give them your money, you won't be disappointed unless you're a total jackass that is impossible to please.**AND, please go read Colleen C's "BYOB etiquette" commentary before going to Tango Sur**

Reviews.Author: Kate O.
Reviews.Content: Sooo yummy!  Pros:  amazing food, Byob, friendly staffCons: very busy, no reservation

Reviews.Author: Mandy A.
Reviews.Content: Things to know when you go here:A) It is LOUD.B) Order lots of empanadas and dump that sauce all over them.C) BYOB but like Colleen says, drink that red wine and get the heck out and go to the bar down the street to linger.D) It is good for groups.E) It is not good for moving around to do things like go to the bathroom.F) Don't bring a big ass purse (you know who you are).G) Don't plan to go out drinking afterwards because you will have a big ass steak in your belly and will be DUN for the night.Cool place and cool atmosphere, great food but wow.  Came here once and they told us 4 hours wait.  Tried again during the week early and it was much better.  Good luck on weekends during the summer.

Reviews.Author: Louisa L.
Reviews.Content: I was a little disappointed with Tango Sur.I had the filet mignon. It wasn't as good as i thought it would be. It wasn't as tender as it should be. On the other hand, the flap meat for two people was very good. I didn't expect the flap meat to be even more tender than my filet mignon. I was disappointed.Portions were HUGE. By the time i finished my steak, i was so full that i couldn't eat my spinach mash potato. The spinach mash potato was so good thou~Empanadas were yummy too~ Baked eggplant was a bit too cheesy. It was overall a nice experience.

Reviews.Author: Albert L.
Reviews.Content: Had dinner here on a Sunday evening.  There was a big line, and apparently it is worse on Fri/Sat's.  Luckily, they have this dark room lit with a couple of candles in the back where they'll open your wine (no corkage fee) and you can drink/chat while you wait.  The 30-45 minutes I waited passed quickly.It was a chilly day, so I requested to be seated inside, although patio seating is available.  The waiter explained the menu to us, and we selected a spinach empanada (Argentinian turnover ), chicken empanada (2$ each), bife de chorizo, and an eggplant dish (one of the few vegetarian dishes available).Atmosphere is loud, and lit with candelight.  It would be perfect place for a first date, if it weren't so loud (unless you have no interest in talking to her).My biggest gripe about the place is that I was definately the most Argentian person in that restaurant.I asked about if they could could make the bife de chorizo "a caballo,"  which means to put two eggs on top of the steak.  The waiter said that they offer the eggs on another entree (some fried fish dish with two eggs), people don't usually order the steak like that.  I'm thinking, "why can't you just take those two eggs and put it on my steak?  I'll pay for the two eggs."  And also having two eggs on your steak is a very, very common occurance in Argentina.The waiter asked how I would like the steak prepared.  I responded with, "a jugoso", which literally means "juicy" and in Argentina it means more-or-less "medium-rare."  The waiter responded with, "Excuse me?"  I then said, "medium-rare."My second biggest gripe was that I felt I was being rushed, or that they have no timing in their food preparation.  After we had finished our empanadas, they brought us the house salads.  We were about 1/4-1/2 done with our salads when they brought our entrees.  I commented to the waiter in Spanish, "Isn't it a bit quick for the entrees already?  We havn't finished our salads."  The waitor responded with, "I'm sorry, but the food would then get cold."  Oh well.Food was okay.  I think the empanadas (particularly the spanish/cheese one tasted great).  Steak was okay (yes, I know that I didn't select the greatest cut, but I know I wasn't going to be impressed with the Canadian beef anyways).Overall, I would return because of the atmosphere and their BYOB policy.  I'm just biased becaused I just returned from 7 days stay in Buenos Aires.

Reviews.Author: ryan w. v.
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to like this place a lot more than I did, but I think I expected too much reading all of the previous reviews from fellow yelpers.  Let me paint the picture...I called on Monday to make a reservation for Tuesday and the dude on the phone told me to call back 1 hour before my arrival time on Tuesday and he would add me to the list.  So, I called back on Tuesday and did just that.  Well, by the time I arrived at Tango Sur, my name wasn't on the list.  I probably would have been pissed at that point, but the harem were all running late so, I added my name to the list and didn't fret.  Luckily once all of the harem arrived we were able to sit down immediately at a table for four outside.  As soon as I sit down, I begin to notice the guitar player return from his break and being to play his musica.  Yes, it's kind of loud and annoying and I didn't really appreciate his musica sitting right next to him.  I'm sure they could plug in an iPod and get the same effect.  Our server was .... pushy.  Yes, I think that's a nice way of putting it.  He was pushy because he asked us what we wanted to order three times before we even opened up the menu.  And when it came to paying for our meal, he came by eight times before we decided we should actually look at the bill and put down some credit.  Regardless of our waiter's eagerness to get us up and out, the bus boys were very attentive with our dirty plates and almost empty glasses.The meal itself was okay.  We decided to order the empanadas and they were very good... actually, the best part of the meal.  I suggest to order the chicken and the spinach & cheese variety.  As for dinner, Nic ordered the eggplant special appetizer thing (because she don't eat no read meat); Mon and Car ordered the Churrasco; and I ordered the Milanesa a La Napolitana which is beef breaded then topped with baked ham, mozzarella and tomato sauce.  I thought it sounded gross, ordered it anyway, and shockingly, found it ... edible.  But, again it was just okay.  I also had a bite of the girls' steak.  Mon ordered it med. rare and Car ordered it med. well.  Car's steak ended up being cooked well and was a little tough.  Mon's was a little too red for my liking, but she likes it red.   ...Irrelevant part of the review...Because we had a long dinner, I couldn't help but notice all of the Southporters making their walks home with Dairy Queen in hand.  I sat in my seat all night watching couple after couple after gay after couple after fat man with baby and skinny wife walk down the street with their DQs.  It made me want a DQ real bad.  ...Back to the review...So, even though I really wanted to love the Tango Sur, I just thought it was okay.  And it's not because I thought there was going to be all these hott Argentinean waiters around because it's an Argentinean restaurant.  I saw some cute male staff working, but am still giving it 3 stars.  3.5 if they had it, but they don't and I'm choosing not round up.

Reviews.Author: Tim Y.
Reviews.Content: Holding steady at two stars after another experience let me down on the service but filled me up with excellent food.We went from an expected 30 minute wait to a 2 minute wait when a table miraculously opened up. Good thing; our bottles of wine did not include a screw-top and none of us had a corkscrew handy. Teeth, broken stemware, and various physics experiments were being considered to get into the juice before sitting down.The usual applies: great food. Just eat whatever you think looks appetizing and you'll be fine. Seriously, I think you'd have to try to find something truly "bad" on the menu.The not so usual also applies: we had two tabletop grill things delivered. One successfully landed with the skill and grace of Apollo 11. The second landed with all the grace of North Korea's last missile test, which is to say it splashed all over the table, my clothes, leg, sock, and shoe. Also the floor, but the floor feels no pain.Though the server quickly said "sorry", he didn't help wipe up the mess he made on the table. He didn't offer another napkin to clean up my clothes nor ask if the really-freaking-hot sauce had burned my leg. Though it did hurt like hell, multiple bottles of wine were had: our doctor-in-a-bottle performed beautifully.The food was good so I didn't mind the fact I was eating on a table swimming with spilled deliciousness. P.S. to the server: yeah, that's right, you took a bottle off our table that still had a glass worth of wine in it. Red card for you, sir. You just don't DO that kind of thing.

Reviews.Author: Melissa T.
Reviews.Content: For years I've been hearing about Tango Sur and last Friday I decided to buy a decent red wine, prepared the palate for red meat, and convinced the boyfriend to wait an hour for dinner.  (They don't take reservations for small parties, i.e. less than 6)We arrived around 7pm on a Friday night and waited a true hour for a table.  Just as everyone mentioned, the restaurant is dim (with candles), tables are close together and it was loud.  (But then again, I'm a loud person so I didn't mind this so much...I can complete with the best of them.)  For appetizers, the waiter suggested the Provoleta and I made sure to order the Empanadas by other's suggestions.  Empanadas, were awesome.  We could've done without the Provolenta, which was just a big plate of melted cheese that you had to race to eat with bread...otherwise it was going to turn into a block within minutes.  The salads came next- which like one reviewer said, were like burger toppings- dark, hearty greens they use on burgers with sliced onions & two large tomato slices.  Yep, that's it.  Not impressed.On to the main dish- I ordered the 12 oz which was cooked well, slightly fatty and heavily seasoned, but tasty.  My boyfriend went for the salmon and it was delicious.  I liked his better and made the switch at the half way point.  The portions were huge and they happily went home with us.  Really, I give it three stars for the portion to price ratio and the ambiance.  Great value but not sure if I'll go back again.

Reviews.Author: Brooke E.
Reviews.Content: I was prepared for the large portion sizes (thanks yelpers) but I didn't understand that "large portions"  at tango sur means when you order a filet, you get two.  Two steaks.  Great for meat enthusiasts, but I was like "What the f--k am I going to do with two steaks?"  When leftovers aren't an option (we were going out right after dinner) this kind of excessive portioning can be frustrating, especially when the steak is good.  Which it was.I had high hopes for the empanadas.  While they were tasty, I don't see them as much more than glorified hot pockets.  But, maybe that's because I had the ham and cheese variety.The bathroom situation (persistent line, tight space) inspired two of my friends to venture outside in the adjacent alley.  The waiter was suspicious, angry even, but you know what? Nobody chooses to leave a restaurant to engage in public urination unless the bathroom situation is truly bad.The "can't be bothered" attitude of the servers made the European atmosphere all the more authentic, and actually was kind of endearing.

Reviews.Author: t. o.
Reviews.Content: Wife was jonesing for steak. Reviews here seemed to warrant a visit. In a word: eh.We started with a selection of empanadas. The pastries were overcooked, and the fillings too paltry to compete with the overwhelming crusts, cooked to too dark a brown. The chimichurri, served with every dish we ordered, had so much raw garlic that nothing else in it was discernible, and further made the fillings just so much hot, flavorless goo.Next was the house salad, which came with the meal. I fair iceberg lettuce salad. Whatever. The steaks, ordered medium rare, were cooked perfectly. No complaints there. I had skirt, wife had flank - which they peculiarly call "flap" on the menu, though luckily the waiter called it what it really is - flank (flap is a totally different cut: a thin, low sirloin. This steak was 3" thick, and clearly a flank.) One bite of the chimichurri (which I pile on when prepared well) wiped out tastebuds for a number of bites. It actually burnt my mouth - and I like garlic. Mushy boiled then baked potatoes (the only side) were likewise slathered in garlic and too much salt. Relentless!Place was ridiculously dark - I appreciate low lighting, but this was like a dungeon. Luckily we arrived early and got a good table by the window, but by the time we left, a line stretched out into the cold night. Service was passable, but you can tell they basically just turn and burn. Prices were moderate ($20-25 per entreee) - would be hard to beat even cooking at home. But with plenty of choices to be had, I won't be back any time soon. Certainly no place to stand in line or brave crowds for.

Reviews.Author: Melissa B.
Reviews.Content: A group of friends and I had dinner here and really enjoyed it!What you read in reviews about the staff being cavalier and the wait for a table being long (but the food being extraordinary) is 100% true.  We made reservations and prepared ourselves for this going in, so our expectations were appropriately set.  I suggest you do the same :-)They are BYOB and don't charge a corkage fee, which keeps the cost super cheap - our bill came to about $45 per couple.  Definitely try the empanadas - the spinach and cheese were so good I ordered a second to eat with my meal.  I ordered Pechuga De Pollo, a grilled chicken breast with chimichurri and steamed veggies.  It was tender, juicy, and a plentiful helping!  I brought half of the butterflied chicken breast home.  The rest of our group ordered steaks and one friend got the breaded chicken with potatoes and loved them.Strap on a laid-back mood and bring a couple bottles of wine if you come to Tango Sur.  There's a great waiting room to chat and sip wine before your table is ready and the food is well worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Matt M.
Reviews.Content: The guys on the door could not have been ruder. We knew we couldn't make a reservation. We arrived at 7pm, were told 90mins wait and they would call us. At 8.45pm we went back and asked if we would be seated soon. We were told 15mins. We went back at 9.10pm and the guys were just rude. They walked away and ignored us when we asked how much longer we would have to wait. Eventually, we asked again and they just said, 20mins and we walked away. Dreadful customer experience.

Reviews.Author: Laura H.
Reviews.Content: A carnivores paradise!!!Initially, i wasnt impressed by the way this place looked and decided to skip going here... Im am so glad I changed my mind! The food, service, and atmosphere blew me away! This tiny little place... gets crowded... but its so quant and romantic with the candles and dim lighting. We started with the empanadas... they were good... and it only got better from there. We ordered the Vacio .... tons of spices and a nice garlicy flavor! It was amazing! The portions are huge... when they say for two, ithey actually mean at least 4! The meat is their specialty... we ordered fries as the side... just cause... and they were OK, but really just go here for the meat!  you wont be disappointed...

Reviews.Author: Kurt L.
Reviews.Content: This quite possibly could be my favorite place in Chicago.  To all the people who hate the long waits and spotty service and any other negatives that are out there.  There is an easy solution to that.  Stop going on the weekends and at peak times!  I go with my girlfriend on a regular basis during the week and it's like night and day!  Grab a bottle of wine or two, a friend or two, and hit the place at like 5:30 or 6pm sometime during the week.  The waiters even remember us now.  The steak is out of this world for the price and the real secret is that everything else is good too.  Give the Pez a try sometime (Fish special) as well as the Pollo Limon.  It's a full half chicken in an amazing lemon butter and spice sauce.  Think chicken oreganato but better.  (I've also noticed it's bigger during the week.)Can't wait for the weather to warm up so we can start sitting outside again.  Nothing better than some wine and people watching out on Southport.

Reviews.Author: Marie B.
Reviews.Content: Hmm.  I am not sure if I was impressed by this place, or not.  I liked the candles and subdued lighting.  Sorta romantic.  I wasn't fond of the generic decorations and uncomfortable chairs, however.  The food was rather good.  Not fabulous, but good.  Solid.  A feast for carnivores!    We asked for our short ribs to be medium well, but they were very well done.  The vesuvio potatoes were divine, however.  The salads were terrible.  Bibb lettuce. Tomatoes. Onion.  That's it.

Reviews.Author: Sonia C.
